results.title: Editing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Covers cutting on action and in terms of graphics; and by following the shooting of a sequence through to the editing of the final product indicates how editing can serve to expand, compress and rearrange time.

results.title: Framing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Looks at the notion of the television camera putting a frame around the world. Discusses on-screen and off-screen space, real and apparent size, and the frame within the frame. Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson.

results.title: Rhythm
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson. Explores rhythm as a fundamental part of the langauge of motion pictures and its integral role in film making. Addresses: 1. Rhythm does not depend on cutting 2. Changes of shot do not necessarily have any special rhythmic effect 3. Music can impose its own rhythm 4. Music and images can work together.

results.title: Orientation of the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Looks at the relationship of the viewer to the screen, and the way in which attention is absorbed into the world of the filmmaker, affecting the viewer’s own orientation. Notes also the physical support of the camera and its orientation in space.

results.title: Movement and moving the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Illustrates movement within the frame, movement of the frame and movement of the camera. Notes the creation of the sense of movement without moving the frame, and how and when the camera can be used subjectively. Narrated by Peter Thompson.

results.title: Lenses and perspective: how does it look from where you are?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Lays to rest the mistaken idea that focal length affects the appearance of depth. Demonstrates that the camera-to-subject distance is the governing factor in the perception of spatial relationships in the third dimension. Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson.

results.title: The Third dimension
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Introduces the idea of optical illusion, and the way it relates to our perception of depth in the two-dimensional image.

results.title: Shot sizes and framing faults: Episode 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Gives working definitions of shot sizes, and shows common framing faults, and how they can be corrected. Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson. From the “Lessons in visual language” series.
